attributes.title: Traveling Jacket
attributes.description: The journey of a simple jacket found at a school. Who made it?Where did the materials come from? Where was it assembled?

Factories like "Esdan Plastics" exist all over the world. I only selected one because it would take too long to label all of the factories. 
"Esdan Plastocs" doesn't solely focus on the creation of nylon, but also other plastics and polymers
 See the video link to see how nylon is made. These chemicals can be acquired any where and are man made, there is no real supplier. 
Once the nylon has been made, it needs to be washed with water or else the stands will fuse together into a single mass due to chemical residue left on the nylon which didn't combine with the other chemicals.
After the nylon has been cleaned, it is shipped off to factories around the world.
attributes.title: Esdan Plastics (Pty) Ltd.

attributes.description: A small store in Brattleboro, Vermont. Carries several brands of out adventure equipment.
attributes.title: Sam's Department Store

attributes.description: Factories take the nylon strands, melt them and cut them to shape, weave into fabric, then trim and sew into clothing. These factories are part of the HERproject and its  female workers are treated fairly and educated about health issues. Both from the work place and personal hygiene, family planning, mental health, and STDs.
attributes.title: Vietnam

attributes.description: Established in 1938, CSC has grown to one of the top producers in outdoor exploration and sport equipment.
attributes.address: 14375 Northwest Science Park Drive, Portland, OR 97229, USA
attributes.title: Columbia Sportswear Company HQ

attributes.description: Head quarters of the "Pacific Trail" incorporation, was founded in 1945. As of March 30th, 2006, it was acquired by Columbia Sportswear Company.
attributes.address: 1700 Westlake Ave N #200, Seattle, WA 98109, USA
attributes.title: Pacific Trail HQ

attributes.description: On June 7, 2012, it was the last day of school. On that day, all objects residing in the "Lost and Found" were displayed for all to see and be claimed by their owners. At the end of the day however, the remaining objects were free for anyone to take. This jacket was one of those objects, which was quickly snagged by myself.
